description: From French déranger, from Old French desrengier (“throw into disorder”), from des- + rengier (“to put into line”), from reng (“line, row”), from a Germanic source. See rank (noun).

verbs.description: derange (third-person singular simple present deranges, present participle deranging, simple past and past participle deranged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly passive) To cause (someone) to go insane or become deranged.
(transitive) To cause disorder in (something); to distort from its ideal state.
(transitive) To cause to malfunction or become inoperative.
(archaic) To disrupt (somebody's) plans, to inconvenience; to derail.
